chapter: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the most potent androgen?
questions.explanation: Dihydrotestosterone is the most potent androgen.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question: Question 2: Aromatase converts testosterone into
questions.explanation:
Aromatase (CYP19) converts testosterone to estradiol. Certain effects of testosterone are mediated 
by estradiol. In men with deficient CYP19 or ER receptors, the epiphyses do not fuse, the long bones grow 
indefinitely and such patients are osteoporotic. Administration of estradiol can correct the bone 
abnormalities in CYP19 deficiency. However, this cannot be used in those with ER receptor 
defects. Testosterone is converted to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by 5-alpha-reductase. Androstanedione and epiandrosterone are metabolites of DHT due to the action of 17-beta-HSD.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question:
Question 3: A 59-year-old man with metastatic prostate cancer is started on flutamide therapy. What is 
the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Flutamide acts by competitive inhibition of androgen receptors and is used to treat prostate 
cancer. Flutamide is a non-steroidal antiandrogen that competes with androgens such as testosterone and 
dihydrotestosterone for binding to the androgen receptors in the prostate gland. By doing so, it 
prevents them from stimulating the prostate cancer cells to grow. In addition to its use in prostate cancer, flutamide has been used to treat hyperandrogenism 
(excess androgen levels) in women, such as in those with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and 691 
Sold by @itachibot Hirsutism. Other anti-androgens are: • Bicalutamide, apalutamide, and nilutamide • Spironolactone (aldosterone antagonist with antiandrogen activity) • Cyproterone acetate (progestin with antiandrogen activity) • Cimetidine (H2 blocker with anti-androgen activity) Selective Androgen Receptor Modulators (SARMs) are a class of androgen receptor ligands that 
have similar anabolic properties to anabolic steroids, but with reduced androgenic side effects. 
There are no FDA-approved SARMs at present.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question:
Question 4: A 25-year-old medical student is worried about his receding hairline and is thinking about 
taking finasteride. The drug enhances hair growth by acting on which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Finasteride is a competitive inhibitor of 5  -reductase enzyme and thereby inhibits the conversion 
of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. Finasteride selectively inhibits the Type 2 isoenzyme of 5 -reductase. It is indicated for use in: • Benign prostatic hyperplasia • Male pattern baldness • Hirsutism.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following inhibits spermatogenesis?
questions.explanation:
Gossypol is a non-steroidal agent that inhibits spermatogenesis. Gossypol is obtained from cottonseed. It inhibits spermatogenesis by exerting toxic effects on 
seminiferous tubules but has low efficacy. Libido and potency are not significantly affected and 
fertility usually returns after a few months of discontinuation of the drug. But, around 10% of the 
patients may remain infertile. Hypokalemia is a major adverse effect and may even lead to 
transient paralysis. Low efficacy and significant toxicity have caused gossypol to be abandoned as a candidate male 
contraceptive.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question:
Question 6: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the urology OPD with complaints of erectile 
dysfunction and was prescribed a PDE-5 inhibitor. Identify the drug.
questions.explanation:
Tadalafil is a PDE-5 inhibitor used in the treatment of patients with erectile dysfunction. Penile erection is mediated by NO and cGMP. During arousal, the corpus cavernosum produces 
nitric oxide which in turn stimulates the formation of cGMP. This leads to relaxation of the 
smooth muscle of corpus cavernosum and penile arteries, causing engorgement of corpus 
cavernosum producing an erection. The biological actions of cGMP are terminated by 692 
Sold by @itachibot phosphodiesterase enzymes and PDE-5 is the major cGMP metabolizing enzyme in the penile 
tissue. Phosphodiesterase-5-inhibitors include: • Sildenafil • Tadalafil - Longest acting (24-36 hrs), bioavailability is not affected by food • Vardenafil • Avanafil - Most Rapid-acting (within 15 -30 mins) Option A: Podofilox topical cream is used in the treatment of genital warts and molluscum 
contagiosum lesions. Option B: Finasteride is a 5  -reductase inhibitor. Option C: Apalutamide is a androgen receptor antagonist.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question:
Question 7: A 40-year-old diabetic patient was prescribed sildenafil for his erectile dysfunction. Following 
this, he develops a blurring of vision and complains that things seem to appear with a 
bluish-green hue. Inhibition of which of the following enzymes is likely to have caused his 
visual side effects?
questions.explanation:
Visual disturbance seen with sildenafil is due to PDE-6 inhibition. Sildenafil is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction principally due to its inhibitory actions 
on PDE-5 (Phosphodiesterase 5) in the vascular tissues of the corpus cavernosa. However, it also 
exerts minor inhibitory action against PDE-6, which is present exclusively in rod and cone 
photoreceptors and results in blurring and blue-green tinting of vision. Tadalafil and avanafil have better PDE-5/PDE-6 selectivity, compared to sildenafil and vardenafil 
and hence have lesser visual side effects.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question:
Question 8: 689 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is a prostaglandin that can be administered as an intracavernosal 
injection for erectile dysfunction?
questions.explanation:
Alprostadil can be given as a direct intracavernosal injection for erectile dysfunction. Alprostadil is a natural PGE1 preparation. It is usually used in patients who are not responding to 
PDE-5 inhibitors. It is also available as an intraurethral suppository.
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question:
Question 9: A 35-year-old physician presented to the ED with a prolonged painful erection induced by 
intracorporeal injection of an alprostadil+phentolamine combination. He had been using this 
technique to overcome occasional performance anxiety. Corporeal aspiration reveals dark 
coloured blood and based on further workup, a diagnosis of low flow priapism is made. 
Which of the following is the drug of choice to treat his condition?
questions.explanation:
Phenylephrine is the drug of choice for the treatment of low flow priapism. Characteristics of low-flow priapism include painful rigid erection and ischemic corpora, indicated 
by dark blood upon corporeal aspiration. Prazosin, and, phenoxybenzamine are alpha-blockers that cause vasodilation and can worsen 
priapism. 693 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction

questions.question:
Question 10: A 19-year-old male athlete seeks your opinion on the usage of anabolic steroids to improve his 
performance. What would be your advice?

options.a: A primiparous woman with spontaneous premature labor
options.b: Vasopressin V2 receptors on luminal surface of renal tubular cells
options.c: Vasopressin V1 receptors on serosal surface of renal tubular cells
options.d: Vasopressin V1 receptors on luminal surface of renal tubular cells

questions.explanation:
All anabolic steroids have significant androgenic action and the use of anabolic steroids by 
athletes is not recommended. Testosterone and its derivatives are used for their anabolic effects but they have significant 
androgenic action. Some of them (17 methyl derivatives) are also hepatotoxic. The current 
consensus is to advise against the use of such anabolic steroids. 694 
Sold by @itachibot Drugs Acting on Uterus
questions.chapter_heading: Androgens and Drugs for Erectile Dysfunction
